H0.text: Impermeable rock layers make up the bottom of an aquifer.

H1.text: Invisible rock layers make up the bottom of an aquifer.

H2.text: Porous rock layers make up the bottom of an aquifer.

H3.text: Crystalline is the type of rock layer that makes up the bottom of an aquifer.

A4.text: Aquitards are composed of layers of either clay or non-porous rock with low hydraulic conductivity.

A5.text: Areas of the Deccan Traps, a basaltic lava formation in west-central India, are examples of rock formations with high porosity but low permeability, making them poor aquifers.
